0<*>.name: The Untrain
0<*>.desc: This... isn't quite a locomotive yet.

desc.2: Congrats, you have just reinvented the board.
desc.5:: Wheels are NOT optional. Fix this.

1.name: Ultra-Wobbly Wagon/Super-Wobbly Wagon/Hyper Wobbly Wagon/Pogo Stick

desc.0: Which rail does this even rest on?
desc.2: Do you have a gyro in there...
desc.3: Are you absolutely sure you know what you're doing?
desc.4: Can we just get back to locomotives?
desc.5:: What is wrong with you! Just make some locomotives!

desc.1: In series, this could be an accordion!
desc.2: I suppose, when connected to another car, this would work?
desc.4: Don't you dare try to make this.
desc.5:: Just get back to actual trains! I would prefer a wagon over this abomination!

desc.0:2: An unsteady wagon for those too cheap to buy a 4th wheel.
desc.3:4: You do know that this notation is for locomotives, right?

desc.0:2: A sturdy wagon with a steady wheel set.
desc.3:4: You do know that this notation is for locomotives, right?

desc.0:2: An less-unsteady wagon for those too cheap to buy a 4th wheel, but who have all the money for the 5th and 6th.
desc.3:4: You do know that this notation is for locomotives, right?

desc.0: It's like a wagon from SPAAAAAAaaaaaAaaaAAAAaaace!
desc.1:2: I think you forgot some other wheel sets. Use a "-" for that purpose.
desc.3:4: Can you just make a normal locomotive?

desc.0:2: Honestly, I didn't think you would get this far...
desc.3: Turn around, there isn't anything important beyound this.
desc.4: Don't make me raise my voice.

desc.0:1: What in the world do you think this app is for?
desc.2: This isn't what a tank car is--try again.
desc.3:4: Please... just get back to normal trains!
desc.5:: I am a peaceful app! I cannot condone this.

desc.0:1: If you're making a tank, can you at least make it symmetrical?
desc.2: I'm happy for you. At least these tanks are defective and can't be used.
desc.3:4: Listen. These don't even have engines. They are just unpoweed wheel sets!

628.name: Tau/τ
628.desc: You disgust me. Taking a perfectly good number and corrupting it by arbitrarily multiplying it. Horrendous!

[51-*].name: Stop!
[51-*].desc: Each wheel set is, like, 5 individual elements for HTML to render! It is highly likely that your compouter hates you.

0-0.name: Under maintanence
0-0.desc: I'm sorry: this piece of rolling equipment is currently under maintainence. Please try again later.

2-2.name: Minecart
2-2.desc: This doesn't look like it will hold much. Are you sure you want to use it?

4-4.name: Freight Wagon
4-4.desc: The basic freight wagon, with a truck on each end to bear the weight

0-0-0.name: A Steam Maglev???/The Hover-Mobile/A Literal Airplane

desc.0:1: How is this even hovering? There aren't any wheels!
desc.2: Do you just like the number 0? Why not try a nice 0-4-0?
desc.3: This is the worst locomotive I've ever seen! I bet it won't even move!

desc.0: Cool! I love a good bike ride, but that doesn't quite fit on the rails...
desc.1:2: While I appreciate the sentiment, let's just get back to trains
desc.3: I guess I can't fault a good bike
desc.4: Listen, I love bikes, but I also love trains. Let's get back to the locomotives
desc.5:: LOCOMOTIVES. Not bikes. Biking later. Not now.

desc.0: This looks a little old... Even for steam trains.
desc.1: Are you sure this is a train?
desc.4: What in the world are you doing with one of these? Are you racing...
desc.5:: If you're going to make a bike. At least make a modern one!

0-1-0.name: One Wheel/No Wheel*/A Wheel/Not Quite No Wheel

desc.1:2: Would you ride this on one of the rails, or in the middle on the trackbed?
desc.3: While I appreciate that this is semi-useful, can we get back to trains?
desc.4: Please, just make an actual locomotive!
desc.5:: Here's a deal: You make a locomotive with METAL wheels, and I won't yell at you

desc.0: Wait... This actually existed as a monorail‽ Why would you use this when two rails work perfectly fine?
desc.2: These things died out for a reason--they have very little, if not no, practical value
desc.3: This doesn't even work as a locomotive, what where you thinking?
desc.4: Maybe turn this into an 0-4-0, that's always a good configuration!

0-2-2.name: Northumbrian
0-2-2.desc: Stephenson's Rocket, the winner of the Rainhill trials, was of this configuration. A nice, simple design.

0-3-0.desc: This wheel arrangement was extremely rare, and only used in specialized monorails. Please, don't make this.

0-4-0.name: Four-Coupled
0-4-0.desc: A great choice for high manouverability and power at low speeds. A great choice for a yard engine!

0-4-2.name: Olomana
0-4-2.desc: This configuration originally started out as a tender engine, but then evolved into a tank engine because...

0-4-4.name: 0-4-4T/Forney Four-Coupled
0-4-4.desc: This was mainly used for passenger service in the US, for navigating the narrow curves of elevated railways.

0-5-0.name: The Hand
0-5-0.desc: Perfect for moving everything around the yard.

0-6-0.name: Six-Coupled/Bourbannais/
0-6-0.desc: Historically, these were the most popular choice for switching locomotives (steam or diesel). Their lack of guide wheels meant that all the weight was concentrated on the powered axles. This allowed for more tractive effort, but with a lower stability at high speed.

0-6-2.name: Branchliner/Webb
0-6-2.desc: The majority of locomotives constructed in this configuration were tank engines.

0-6-4.name: Forney Six-Coupled
0-6-4.desc: Something, something, history of the class, et. cetera...

0-6-6.name: Forney Six-Coupled
0-6-6.desc: These locomotives were only produced as tank engines, with their large amount of trailing axles acting as great support for an integrated tender.

0-10-0.name: Eight-Coupled
0-10-0.desc: A good switcher, but getting a little large.

desc.0:3: This is just slightly too big, don't you think?
desc.4:: You spent so much time wondering whether you could, you never stopped to consider the minimum radius turn this locomotive could take.

2-2-0.name: Planet
2-2-0.desc: A good choice in the early-mid 1800s. Nowadays... not so much.

2-2-2.name: Single/Jenny Lind/Patentee
2-2-2.desc: Like a 2-2-0, but better... I hope?

2-2-4.name: 2-2-4T
2-2-4.desc: A little rare. This was only used a few specialized tank engines.

2-4-0.name: Porter/Hanscom/Old English/Light Passenger
2-4-0.desc: An enlargement of the 2-2-0 and 2-2-2 types. This gave more tractive effort for a relatively similar footprint.

2-4-2.name: Columbian/Light Passenger
2-4-2.desc: Named after the Baldwin Locomotive Works' 2-4-2, showcased at the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition. This was widely used on tank engines, and is well suited to bi-directional operation due to the symmetrical wheel arrangement.

2-4-4.name: 2-4-4T/Forney
2-4-4.desc: This wheel arrangement was only used for tank engines.

2-6-0.name: Mogul
2-6-0.desc: This configuration was popularized before the use of separate trucks. As such, the leading wheels were bolted to a rigid frame, making a large portion of locomotives with this configuration essentially 0-8-0s with unpowered front axles.
2-6-0.example: CN E-10-a/Finnish class Sk1/C1218/GS&WR Class 355/Class NG7

2-6-2.name: Prairie
2-6-2.desc: Due to its symmetry, this configuration can be unstable. The center of gravity is centered around the central driven wheel. As such, the reciprocating motion of the rods can cause the locomotive to sway at high speeds.

desc.0: Almost exclusively used as a tank engine.
desc.1: Lionel would like to know your location.
desc.2: Be real with me for a moment: Is this a model you stole from some large 3-rail O-scale brand? I won't tell... For a price.
desc.3:5: Give it here. Let me show you how to properly operate this locomotive. No, you don't touch the controls: Just watch as I... teach you. Choo choo!

desc.0:2: You've heard of a Mogul, right? Well, imagine that, but with more wheels. I know what your thinking but--wait, these actually work? And were somehow basically the best. WHAT?
desc.3:: Hello Pennsylvania railroad. How are things going?

2-8-2.name: Mikado/Macarthur
2-8-2.desc: A nice improvement on the famous 2-8-0. But not as popular. Great for freight or low-speed passenger service.
2-8-2.example: USRA No. 639/Katanga Mikado No. 201/China Railways SY No 1000/Class Tr1 No. 1088/DRB Class 41

2-8-4.name: Berkshire/Kanawha

desc.0:1: A 2-8-2, but with a larger firebox for upgraded pulling capacity
desc.2:4: 2-8-2++. Like C++ is to C, except better in every way and without OOP
desc.5: Pretty good choice, I must grudgingly admit.

2-8-4.example: Nickel Plate Roat 765/WAGR K/BBÖ Class 114/Deutsche Bundesbahn Class 65/Soviet Class IS

desc.0:2: You heard what happened with the Consolidation, right? Well let's try it again. If some is greaty, then more must be amazing--oh.
desc.3:4: You could have stopped with the 2-8-0, you know?
desc.5: Too many wheels. I am putting my foot down--Read my lips: A.R.T.I.C.U.L.A.T.I.O.N.

2-10-2.name: Santa Fe

desc.0:2: It's like a 2-10-0, but with the capability for a larger firebox!
desc.3: I can the idea and potential, and it does seem to work.
desc.4: Stop adding wheels! Can you keep the driving wheels below 10 please!
desc.5: Wasn't the Decapod enough? You just slapped more insanity onto a beast that shouldn't exist!

2-10-2.example: ATSF Tandem Compound/QJ/Prussian T 20 class BR95/CFM class 250/PKP Class OKz32/RENFE 151.5001

2-10-4.name: Texas
2-10-4.desc: Used to pull massive loads. As you can imagine, this had a huge firebox, and put it to work!
2-10-4.example: ATSF 5001/Canadian Pacific T1c/ATSF No. 5000/Soviet class OR23

4-2-0.name: Jervis
4-2-0.desc: Named after the inventer, this was a good way for the Americans to replace rigid 0-4-0s with a more flexible wheel arrangement, to help navigate tighter curves.

4-2-2.desc: These were manufactured in the era before independent bogies--the entire wheelbase was on one solid frame. As you would imagine, this wasn't great for navigating curves or wheel adhesion.

4-2-4.name: 4-2-4T
4-2-4.desc: This design was only used on tank engines. It used an unflanged driving wheel, relying entirely on the undriven wheelsets to guide the locomotive.

4-4-0.name: American Standard/Eight-Wheeler
4-4-0.desc: This configuration was extremely popular in the mid-1800s, and is a necessity for any movie depicting the "Old West". The ceremony of the completion of the Transcontinental Railroad was headed by two 4-4-0s--the Jupiter and 119!
4-4-0.example: Jupiter/119/Hercules/Finnish Class A4/Beira Railway Falcon F2

4-4-2.name: Atlantic/Chautauqua/Milwaukee
4-4-2.desc: This configuration was largely used for passenger service around 1895 in the US. The rear trailing wheels gave it higher stability at higher speeds.
4-4-2.example: Milwaukee Road class A2/KFNB IId Class/Prussian S 7 Class/Japanese 6600 Class

4-4-4.name: Reading/Jubilee/Lady Baltimore
4-4-4.desc: A fast, light-duty locomotive for hauling... stuff.

4-6-0.name: Ten Wheeler
4-6-0.desc: "As the 2-8-0 is to freight, the 4-6-0 is to passengers" - Hyce
4-6-0.example: Canadian National E-10-a/Finish class SK1/C1218/Midland Railway 2510/SP 1744/WDWRR No. 2

4-6-2.name: Pacific

desc.0: Big wheels, big firebox, big on stability. What's not to like?
desc.1:: "THE passenger locomotive of all time" - Hyce

4-6-2.example: Q class/K5/LNER Peppercorn/LNER A4/Canadian Pacific G3c

4-6-4.name: Huson

desc.0: An improved 4-4-4. When you need to haul a lot of cargo and you need to get to wherever you're going quickly.
desc.2:5: An improved 4-4-4. When you need to haul a lot of cargo and you need to get to wherever you're going quickly.

4-6-4.example: NGR Class H/Victorian Railways R class/Canadian Pacific 2816/Finish VR Class Pr2/05.001

desc.0:3: Sligtly atypical, and not entirely standard. But I suppose it'll work.
desc.4:5: I didn't mean for you to move the wheels to the trailing set. I just wanted you to REmove them!

desc.0:3: Leading wheels are great, but driving wheels are even better! Or at least the inventor of this class believed.

4-8-2.name: Mountain/Mohawk
4-8-2.desc: Great for freight at higher speeds. Lots of power, and presumably stable.
4-8-2.example: NGR Class D/NGR Class B/WAGR W/SNCF Class 241P/Pu29/Class 4/Class 12R

4-8-4.name: Northern/Niagra/Confederation/Dixie/Greenbrier/Pocono/Potomac/Heavy Mtn/Golden State/Western/General/Wyoming/Big Apple
4-8-4.desc: Do you want to move some freight and passengers in luxery, style, and modernity. Say no more. Introducing the 4-8-4: The only class garunteed to gain my approval.

desc.0:1: Taking the 4-X-0 series to its logical conclusion.
desc.2-3: Have you considered adding some trailing wheels? They would help loads with your inevitable stability issues
desc.4: This may not be the right job for you. Have you looked into NASA rover designs? They seem to like wheels, and I would have to see them!

desc.0: Useful when the 4-10-0 doesn't quite cut it for your speed.
desc.1: Thank you for the purchase of two trailing wheels from the 2-10-0 starter pack. We hope you enjoy!
desc.2: Now that you have all these wheels, you should really look at the Big Boy. Do you understand the point I am trying to ARTICULATE?
desc.3:5: Please stop with all the wheels. This is just getting worse and worse...

desc.0: A huge amount of pulling power. Just don't expect to take any turns in it.
desc.1: This is 'Murica. If you want to be better than the rest, UP has got your back.
desc.2: Hyce says that this has enough power to pull all of Nebraska. I am inclined to believe him.
desc.3: Are you trying to challenge Soviet-era Russian engineering? You are bound to fail.
desc.4:5: Stop it with the wheels! The Russians did it better than you ever will!

desc.5: One word: Articulation. If an articulated 4-4-4-4 can exist, you can break up your 7 precious axles.

6-2-0.name: Crampton
6-2-0.desc: This is a very strange wheel arrangement for a very strange locomotive. Placing most of the weight on the leading wheels, this arrangement was only useful for the Crampton locomotive. This had a low, long boiler, with the firebox centered over the single driven axle.
